Performing PCA and FA

Rob Kabacoff

2022-03-06

Source: vignettes/factorAnalysis.Rmd
factorAnalysis.Rmd

The qacDR package provides functions for principal components and common factor analysis. Based on the William Revelle’s comprehensive package, the package provides simplified input, intuitive output, and easily interpretable graphs, making these techniques more accessible to data analysts new to these forms of analysis.

Principal Components Analysis

Let’s perform a principal components analysis on some ratings data. First we’ll import the data into R.

# input data
ratings <- read.csv("https://www.promptcloud.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/EFA.csv")
head(ratings)
#>   Price Safety Exterior_Looks Space_comfort Technology After_Sales_Service
#> 1     4      4              5             4          3                   4
#> 2     3      5              3             3          4                   4
#> 3     4      4              3             4          5                   5
#> 4     4      4              4             3          3                   4
#> 5     5      5              4             4          5                   4
#> 6     4      4              5             3          4                   5
#>   Resale_Value Fuel_Type Fuel_Efficiency Color Maintenance Test_drive
#> 1            5         4               4     2           4          2
#> 2            3         4               3     4           3          2
#> 3            5         4               5     4           5          4
#> 4            5         5               4     4           4          2
#> 5            5         3               4     5           5          5
#> 6            3         4               3     2           3          2
#>   Product_reviews Testimonials
#> 1               4            3
#> 2               2            2
#> 3               4            3
#> 4               5            3
#> 5               5            2
#> 6               2            3

Next, well create a scree plot of the data.

library(qacDR)

# scree plot
scree_plot(ratings)

The scree plot suggests four components. In the next step, we’ll extract four principal components and rotate them using a varimax rotation.

# extract 2 principal components
fit.pca <- PCA(ratings, nfactor=4, rotate="varimax")
#> 
#> Principal Components Analysis
#> Number of Factors: 4 Rotation: varimax 
#> 
#> Component Structure
#>                       PC1   PC2   PC3   PC4   h2
#> Price                0.71  0.13 -0.05 -0.13 0.54
#> Safety              -0.37  0.50 -0.27  0.15 0.49
#> Exterior_Looks       0.03  0.05  0.27 -0.78 0.69
#> Space_comfort       -0.03  0.76  0.23 -0.24 0.68
#> Technology           0.04  0.49  0.11  0.01 0.26
#> After_Sales_Service  0.14  0.66  0.12  0.20 0.51
#> Resale_Value         0.78 -0.14 -0.14  0.08 0.65
#> Fuel_Type            0.07  0.70 -0.05 -0.11 0.51
#> Fuel_Efficiency      0.51  0.24  0.36  0.37 0.59
#> Color                0.19 -0.05  0.28  0.76 0.69
#> Maintenance          0.68  0.08  0.13  0.27 0.56
#> Test_drive           0.05  0.15  0.63 -0.01 0.42
#> Product_reviews      0.38  0.14  0.55  0.02 0.47
#> Testimonials        -0.30 -0.03  0.76  0.01 0.67
#> 
#>                    PC1  PC2  PC3  PC4
#> Variance          2.27 2.13 1.76 1.56
#> Var Explained     0.16 0.15 0.13 0.11
#> Cum Var Explained 0.16 0.31 0.44 0.55

The four components account for 55% of the variance in the original data. Next, we’ll plot the pattern matrix as both a table and a bar chart.

# plot factor pattern as bar chart
plot(fit.pca, sort=TRUE)


# plot factor pattern as a table
plot(fit.pca, sort=TRUE, type="table")

Finally, we’ll add the component scores to the original data.

# save component scores
mydata <- score(ratings, fit.pca)
head(mydata)
#>   Price Safety Exterior_Looks Space_comfort Technology After_Sales_Service
#> 1     4      4              5             4          3                   4
#> 2     3      5              3             3          4                   4
#> 3     4      4              3             4          5                   5
#> 4     4      4              4             3          3                   4
#> 5     5      5              4             4          5                   4
#> 6     4      4              5             3          4                   5
#>   Resale_Value Fuel_Type Fuel_Efficiency Color Maintenance Test_drive
#> 1            5         4               4     2           4          2
#> 2            3         4               3     4           3          2
#> 3            5         4               5     4           5          4
#> 4            5         5               4     4           4          2
#> 5            5         3               4     5           5          5
#> 6            3         4               3     2           3          2
#>   Product_reviews Testimonials        PC1        PC2        PC3          PC4
#> 1               4            3  0.7867142 -0.6023290 -1.0316667 -1.782979593
#> 2               2            2 -1.6512802 -0.3916004 -2.6037457  1.215843878
#> 3               4            3  1.0231012  0.4978477 -0.2983645  1.116453440
#> 4               5            3  0.8430586 -0.6401250 -0.8881818  0.003804657
#> 5               5            2  1.5060337 -0.0459925 -0.2881563  0.521230308
#> 6               2            3 -0.6483141 -0.3717037 -1.7763823 -1.513013644

Factor Analysis

In this section, the ratings data are re-analyzed using a maximum likelihood factor analysis.

Again, we’ll start with a scree plot. This time we’ll run 200 simulations. A random number seed is set to assure reproducability.

library(qacDR)

# scree plot
set.seed(1234)
scree_plot(ratings, method = "ml", n.iter=200)

Again, the scree plot suggests two factors. In the next step, we’ll extract four factors and rotate them using a promax rotation.

# extract 4 factors
fit.fa <- FA(ratings, nfactor=4, rotate="promax", fm="ml")
#> 
#> Maximum Likelihood Factor Analysis
#> Number of Factors: 4 / Rotation: promax 
#> 
#> Factor Pattern
#>                        F1    F2    F3    F4   h2
#> Price                0.56  0.10 -0.09 -0.09 0.29
#> Safety              -0.24  0.40 -0.19  0.06 0.21
#> Exterior_Looks      -0.02  0.03  0.19 -0.43 0.21
#> Space_comfort       -0.08  0.78  0.16 -0.20 0.71
#> Technology           0.00  0.35  0.05  0.04 0.13
#> After_Sales_Service  0.18  0.42  0.02  0.02 0.25
#> Resale_Value         0.84 -0.22 -0.25 -0.08 0.61
#> Fuel_Type            0.04  0.59 -0.07 -0.06 0.34
#> Fuel_Efficiency      0.45  0.11  0.22  0.16 0.42
#> Color                0.00 -0.07  0.27  0.90 0.90
#> Maintenance          0.58  0.06 -0.01  0.20 0.45
#> Test_drive           0.04  0.05  0.42 -0.06 0.21
#> Product_reviews      0.24  0.08  0.41  0.00 0.33
#> Testimonials        -0.39 -0.09  0.76  0.06 0.49
#> 
#> Factor Structure
#>                        F1    F2    F3    F4
#> Price                0.52  0.16  0.14  0.06
#> Safety              -0.23  0.31 -0.17  0.00
#> Exterior_Looks      -0.05  0.06  0.17 -0.42
#> Space_comfort        0.05  0.80  0.33 -0.19
#> Technology           0.09  0.36  0.15  0.05
#> After_Sales_Service  0.27  0.46  0.21  0.08
#> Resale_Value         0.70 -0.15  0.00  0.13
#> Fuel_Type            0.09  0.57  0.10 -0.03
#> Fuel_Efficiency      0.58  0.24  0.42  0.28
#> Color                0.32  0.03  0.30  0.91
#> Maintenance          0.64  0.15  0.22  0.35
#> Test_drive           0.19  0.17  0.45 -0.03
#> Product_reviews      0.40  0.23  0.52  0.08
#> Testimonials        -0.11  0.06  0.60 -0.01
#> 
#>                         F1   F2   F3   F4
#> SS loadings           1.76 1.51 1.13 1.14
#> Proportion Var        0.13 0.11 0.08 0.08
#> Cumulative Var        0.13 0.23 0.32 0.40
#> Proportion Explained  0.32 0.27 0.20 0.21
#> Cumulative Proportion 0.32 0.59 0.79 1.00
#> 
#> Factor Intercorrelations
#>      F1   F2   F3   F4
#> F1 1.00 0.16 0.37 0.26
#> F2 0.16 1.00 0.27 0.03
#> F3 0.37 0.27 1.00 0.04
#> F4 0.26 0.03 0.04 1.00

The printout includes the factor pattern, the factor structure, and the factor intercorrelations. The four factors account for 40% of the variance in the original data. The largest factor intercorrelation is between factor 1 and factor 3 (0.37) .

Next, we’ll plot the pattern matrix as both a table and a bar chart.

# plot factor pattern as table
plot(fit.fa, sort=TRUE)


# plot factor pattern as bar chart
plot(fit.fa, sort=TRUE, type="table")

Finally, we’ll add the factor scores to the original data.

# save component scores
mydata <- score(ratings, fit.fa)
head(mydata)
#>   Price Safety Exterior_Looks Space_comfort Technology After_Sales_Service
#> 1     4      4              5             4          3                   4
#> 2     3      5              3             3          4                   4
#> 3     4      4              3             4          5                   5
#> 4     4      4              4             3          3                   4
#> 5     5      5              4             4          5                   4
#> 6     4      4              5             3          4                   5
#>   Resale_Value Fuel_Type Fuel_Efficiency Color Maintenance Test_drive
#> 1            5         4               4     2           4          2
#> 2            3         4               3     4           3          2
#> 3            5         4               5     4           5          4
#> 4            5         5               4     4           4          2
#> 5            5         3               4     5           5          5
#> 6            3         4               3     2           3          2
#>   Product_reviews Testimonials         F1         F2         F3         F4
#> 1               4            3  0.2506910 -0.4699041 -0.7872106 -1.6945115
#> 2               2            2 -1.5335845 -0.9639319 -2.4591528  0.8789180
#> 3               4            3  1.1462512  0.2886700 -0.1155376  0.4665338
#> 4               5            3  0.5241452 -0.8581296 -0.6791612  0.4143127
#> 5               5            2  1.3108167  0.1322874 -0.1696281  1.3488528
